record.dc:title: 5RE12 DeArmond Site 2RE12, Roane Co., TN. Feature 2, a north-south cross-section view of kettle shaped pit showing contents of charred wood on bottom, overlying layer of ash, and upper layer of mussel shell, stones and midden soil. Central mass of loam and large stone in upper section apparently dropped from above. Sq. 35L12-13. Direction east.
record.wpa:narrative: This pit was almost identical with Feature 1 pit. It was circular in shape with a narrower top circumference, giving it a kettle-shaped body form. The cross-section view on back shows distribution of pit contents. The bottom of the pit was covered with a layer of charred saplings, over which was a layer of ash, and above this a layer of mussel shells and midden soil and stones. The central mass of loam soil and large rock seems to have dropped in from above. Sherds examined were grit or limestone tempered. The pit most likely was used for cooking purposes and its proximity to Feature 1 pit and the fact that they both originated at about the same level, suggest that they may have been in use simultaneously.
record.wpa:comments: Observer illustrations on file at the institution.
